Funding Text 1: This is measured by three indicators: international to domestic student ratio, international to domestic staff ratio and the proportion of research that involves international collaboration. These criteria provide a higher weighting for universities with a high number of international students, staff and collaborations. A university seeking to increase its position in the Times Rankings is incentivised to increase its international staff and student numbers. Employing international staff over national candidates decreases the likelihood of Australian archaeology graduates being employed in academic institutions in their home country. The COVID-19 crisis has also revealed the folly of universities being financially dependent on overseas students, with the humanities also impacted by an intended decrease in financial support from the Australian government (Australian Academy of Humanities ).

Funding Text 1: To be successful you will also have to think nationally. National research funding programs include the National Science Foundation in the USA, the Australian Research Council, and the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council in Canada, or the Ministry of Economy and competitiveness in Spain. Think also in terms of federal programs aimed at promoting cultural heritage. Potential funders here include the Wenner-Gren Foundation (), the National Geographic Society (), the Getty Foundation (), and the European Union (European Commission ). Often countries have reciprocal agreements and these can be a source of project funding. The most notable example here is the Fulbright program (Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs ), which operates in 78 countries. Groups such as Earthwatch () have an interest in archaeological and cultural projects and can help organize groups of volunteers to help with surveys and excavations. However, in return you have to be prepared to ‘entertain’ volunteers with after-hours talks and slideshows.
